citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility did not follow their attending veterinarian's care plan for a 6-year old female cockatiel with a feather condition.
On March 15, 2025, "Bibi" was taken to the attending veterinarian for significant feather loss on the head and neck. The
medical record prescribes husbandry changes to start, which the facility implemented. The medical record also directs the
facility to arrange a recheck exam in 1 month and recommends several diagnostic tests (full bloodwork, viral testing, fecal
testing, and x-rays) if the bird's feather condition didn't improve.
At the time of inspection (September 4, 2025, about 6 months later), the inspector observed that the bird was quiet and
still had significant feather loss on the head and neck. A facility representative reported that the husbandry changes did
not appear to improve the bird's feather condition. However, this was not conveyed to the attending veterinarian, and the
facility did not arrange the recheck exam or diagnostic testing.
Failing to follow the veterinarian's discharge instructions for this animal is preventing the attending veterinarian from
ensuring the provision of adequate veterinary care and ensuring this animal's good health.
Correct by arranging a recheck examination with the attending veterinarian for the bird and continuing to follow the
attending veterinarian's recommendations. Exhibitors shall ensure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate
authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care
and use.
Correction date: September 12, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility did not follow their attending veterinarian's care plan for a 6-year old female cockatiel with a feather condition. 
 
On March 15, 2025, "Bibi" was taken to the attending veterinarian for significant feather loss on the head and neck. The 
medical record prescribes husbandry changes to start, which the facility implemented. The medical record also directs the 
facility to arrange a recheck exam in 1 month and recommends several diagnostic tests (full bloodwork, viral testing, fecal 
testing, and x-rays) if the bird's feather condition didn't improve. 
 
At the time of inspection (September 4, 2025, about 6 months later), the inspector observed that the bird was quiet and 
still had significant feather loss on the head and neck. A facility representative reported that the husbandry changes did 
not appear to improve the bird's feather condition. However, this was not conveyed to the attending veterinarian, and the 
facility did not arrange the recheck exam or diagnostic testing.  
 
Failing to follow the veterinarian's discharge instructions for this animal is preventing the attending veterinarian from 
ensuring the provision of adequate veterinary care and ensuring this animal's good health.  
 
Correct by arranging a recheck examination with the attending veterinarian for the bird and continuing to follow the 
attending veterinarian's recommendations. Exhibitors shall ensure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate 
authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care 
and use. 
 
Correction date: September 12, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
